review.title: On interestingness measures of formal concepts
review.abstract: Formal concepts and closed itemsets proved to be of big importance for knowledge discovery, both as a tool for concise representation of association rules and a tool for clustering and constructing domain taxonomies and ontologies. Exponential explosion makes it difficult to consider the whole concept lattice arising from data, one needs to select most useful and interesting concepts. In this paper interestingness measures of concepts are considered and compared with respect to various aspects, such as efficiency of computation and applicability to noisy data and performing ranking correlation.

metadata.title: On interestingness measures of formal concepts∗

sections.text: Key words: Formal concept analysis, Intrestingess measures, closed items.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction and Motivation
sections.text: However, most of the difficulties in applying closed systems to practical datasets are caused by the exponential number of formal concepts. It complicates both the process of model construction and the analysis of results. Recently, several approaches have been introduced to address these problems, which relate to a closed number of attributes calculated through the inclusion of formal concepts. Both the terminology of concept construction and the analysis of results have been used. In relation to FCA, a concept consisting of a pair consisting of a closed set of transactions and an intention (the respective closed item set) is a concept. We propose to divide existing approaches to simplify concepts into the groups represented in Figure 1. Methods of the first group provide a complete set of modified data.

sections.heading: 2 Formal Concept Analysis: Basic Definitions
sections.text: Here we briefly recall the most important terms of the FCA [4]. In view of a finite set of objects G and a finite set of attributes M, we consider an incidence relationship I as a cartesian product G · M, i.e., (g, m) "I," if an object g "G" has an attribute m "M." A formal context is an atripel (G, M, I). The derivative operator (·) "is the set of attributes common to all objects of A and B. The dual application of (·)" is a closure operator, i.e. (·) "A" is extensive, idempotent and monotonous. "Sets A G, B M" is the set of objects that have all attributes of B. The dual application of (·) "is a closure operator, i.e. (·)" A "is a closure element, i.e. (·)" A "is an extensive, ideotonand monoton."

sections.heading: 3 Closed itemset indices
sections.text: The application of the indices offers advantages over other approaches to reducing the number of concepts analyzed. For example, it provides a comprehensive study of a full grid calculated only once, and ensures easy-to-interpret results by obtaining objects and attributes that correspond exactly to the original data.The exponential time complexity of the grid calculation, which accompanies the growing size of the analytical data, attaches particular importance to antimonotonic indices because they allow only a subset of formal concepts.In this section, we examine existing indices proposed for closed item sets using the apparatus of FCA Theory. We describe the most important index attributes and use them to form a concept grid. Below, the main characteristics of indices are described.

sections.heading: 3.1 Description of Index Characteristics
sections.text: Some of the original concepts for evaluating concepts ("designed for closed itemsets") cannot be applied to any item ("not apply to arbitrary itemsets"), while others were originally conceived as arbitrary itemset metrics. In our study, we consider only two arbitrary itemset indices, namely their meaning in the concept mining.There are indices that deal with each attribute of an intention (or an entire context) and evaluate the contribution of these components to a concept ("using all of the single attributes of a context"). Another essential feature of the concept indices is the use of other concepts that are based on comparison with other attributes.

sections.heading: 3.2 Description of Indices
sections.text: In our study, we use the indices described below.

sections.heading: 3.2.1 Stability
sections.text: Stability indices for formal concepts were introduced in [18, 19] and modified in [20]. For formal concepts (A, B), the (holistic) intentional stability index is the probability that B will remain closed if a subset of objects is removed with equal probability from the magnitude A. Intentional stability is defined as follows: Stable (A, B) = | {C A | C ′ = B} | 2 | A | Intentional stability measures overlap, i.e. the dependence of an intention (i.e. a closed pattern) on observations (objects of the respective magnitude). Extensional stability is defined dual. In [21] it was pointed out that stability indices are an anti-monotonic chain of projections. This class of antimonicity contains previously known classes [22] and enables k to generate stable concepts with delayed polynomials in k and the input size.

sections.heading: 3.2.2 Robustness
sections.text: The robustness [22] of an (arbitrary) number resulting from a data set results from the following formula: A = (A, B) stability of the concept (A, B) stability (A, B) stability (A, B) stability (A, B) stability (A, B) stability (A, B) stability (A, B) stability (A, B) stability (A) stability (A) stability (A, B) stability (B) stability (B) stability (A, B) stability (A, B) stability (A, B) stability (A, B) stability (A) stability (A, B) stability (A) stability (A) stability (A, A) stability (A) stability (A) stability (A) stability (A) stability (B) follows stability (B).

sections.heading: 3.2.3 Stability Indices
sections.text: The concept of stability has been revised and taken into account for the estimation of concept-based hypotheses in [19]. In the paper, the stability index is examined in the same way: For formal concepts, c = (A, B) is defined as the stability index of the jth level (2 ≤ j ≤ n − 1) as follows: JJ (c) = γj (c) (n j), where n = |, γj (c) = | {Y-A | | J, Y ′ = B} |. Integrated stability index is defined as JΣ (c) = ∑ n − 1 i = 2 Ji. In this study, we also consider integral stability indices of the jth level (2 ≤ j ≤ n − 1): - Integrated stability on the basis of small amounts: J (c) = хj i = 2 Ji - Major-set-based integral stability: Jig (c) = 1 = j JI.

sections.heading: 3.2.4 Estimates of stability
sections.text: Logarithmic stability The problem of computational stability is # P -complete [19], which hinders its application in practice (IE), where one is normally confronted with large-format contexts. In [24] it was proposed to use the Monte Carlo approach to stability, in [26] combination of mind and upper estimation is described. Authors use the logarithmic stability scale (the concept of ranking remains the same): LBar (c) = − log2 (1 − bar (c)))) It allows to deal with the problem described in [27] that the proximity of stability values to 1 is for large contexts. Limits of stability are defined by the minimum (c) -log2 (| M | log2) -log2 (D). D (c, d).

sections.heading: 3.2.5 Concept Probability
sections.text: The definition of the concept probability of [29] corresponds to the concept probability previously introduced by R. Emilion [30]. The probability that any object has all the attributes of sentence B is defined as follows: pB = 0m ² B pmConcept probability is defined as the probability that B is inferred: p (B = B ²) = n ² k = 0p (| B ² | = k, B ²) = n ² k = 0 [pkB (1 − pB) n − k ² m (1 − pkm)] where the concept probability comprises three probable components: the occurrence of each attribute from B in all k objects, the absence of at least one attribute from B in other objects, and the absence of all other attributes from k.

sections.heading: 3.2.6 Separation
sections.text: The index was introduced in [29] to estimate the specificity of the object-attribute relationship of a concept in relation to the formal context. It is defined as a part of the area covered by a formal concept among all the unequal elements in the rows and columns corresponding to the formal concept. (A, B) = | A | | B | ∑ g ⟩ A | g ′ | + ∑ m ² B | m ² | − | A | | B |

sections.heading: 3.2.7 Monocle
sections.text: The monocle [31] is a method that defines concept weights on the basis of a subset of concepts.The weight function has the following form: w (c, H) = | A | + ∑ g-A NG (g, H) · (| B | + ∑ m-B NM (g, H)), where NG (g, H) = | {(A, B) | (A, B) хH, g / ĝA} | is the number of concepts in H that do not contain an object g, NM (m, H) is similarly defined for attributes, H-L. The weight function is monotonous w.r.t. the size of H.

sections.heading: 3.2.8 δ-Tolerance Closed Frequent Itemsets (δ-TCFIs)
sections.text: δ-TCFI [32] uses a subset of children in a grid to evaluate a concept, the basic idea being to delete concepts that are close in frequency to their direct offspring. Concept c = (A, B) is δ-TCFI if it meets the following condition: Δd = (C, D), so that | D | = | B | + 1, supp (D) ≥ (1 − δ) · supp (B), where δ [0, 1] is a tolerance factor.

sections.heading: 3.2.9 Margin-closed itemset
sections.text: The index was proposed by Moerchen et al. [33]. A Margin Closed Itemset does not have supersets with almost equal support, by definition, the following expression suffices: X-FI & VP-FI: X-X-supp (X) supp (X) ≤ 1 − α, where FI is a series of common items.As can be seen from the formulas, Margin Closed Itemset and δ-TCFIs indices are very close to each other, and are based on the same indices calculated on different subsets of concepts.In our study, we consider the relaxed formulation of the Margin Closed Itemset Index, namely the ratio of the maximum magnitude between all direct predecessors of a concept to the size of the concept itself. Belohlavek and Trnecka examined the group of so-called "basic level" formulas in [34, 35]. It is a psychologically motivated approach aimed at summarizing the basic category of the psychological indicators and one of the psychological indicators.

sections.heading: 3.2.10 Similarity approach (S)
sections.text: The similarity approach to assessing basic-level affiliation was proposed in [37] and subsequently formalized and applied to FCA in [34]. This index is the combination of three blurred functions corresponding to formalized characteristics outlined by E.Rosch [37]: high cohesion of concepts, significantly greater cohesion in relation to upper neighbors and slightly lower cohesion in relation to lower neighbors. The base-level membership level is defined as: BLS = coh threshold (A, B) coh threshold of concepts, greater cohesion in relation to upper neighbors and slightly lower cohesion in relation to lower neighbors (A, B). The base-level membership level is defined as follows: BLS = coh threshold of authors (A, B) coh-coh threshold of authors un (A, B) coh-coh-coh threshold of other neighbors (B).

sections.heading: 3.2.11 Predictability approach (P)
sections.text: In this approach, a cohesion function is replaced by the prediction function: P (A, B) = pred к (A, B) pred й * un (A, B) pred й un (A, B) pred й n (A, B). From this point of view, concepts of the basic level are closed when there are few attributes outside B contained in objects of A: E (I [< x, y > I] | I [x-A]] = − | A-y | | A-log | A-y | | A-pred (A, B) = 1 − cal y-M − BE (I [< x, y > I] | I [x-A]) | M − B |.

sections.heading: 3.2.12 Cue Validity (CV), Category Feature Collocation (CFC), Category Utility (CU)
sections.text: The following measurements are based on the conditional probability of the object g "A given y" g "[35]: CV (A, B) =" y "B" P (A | y ") =" y "Y" Y (A, B) = "y" M (A | y ") p (y" | A) = "y" Y "Y" Y "Y" Y "Y" Y "Y" Y "Y" Y "Y" Y "Y" Y "Y" Y "Y" Y "Y" Y "Y" Y "Y" Y "Y" (A, A) Y "Y" Y "(A, A) Y" Y "(A, A) Y" Y "Y" "Y" "" Y "" (A, B) Y "Y" Y "" Y "" 2 "Y" (A, A).

sections.heading: 3.2.13 Frequency(support)
sections.text: Frequency is one of the most popular parameters in the theory of pattern mining. Frequency results from the assumption that the "most interesting" concepts are frequent: supp (A, B) = | A | | G | The carrier provides an efficient level-oriented algorithm for the semigrid calculation, since it has antimonotonicity (a priori property [40, 41]): B1, B2, supp (B1) ≥ supp (B2).

sections.heading: 3.3 Concept Lattice of Indices for Closed Itemsets
sections.text: We consider the indices described above and their characteristics in the form of the formal context presented in Table 1 to be interesting, the corresponding grid is based on 73 formal concepts. We have applied indices to the grid and considered top 8 concepts (about 10% of all concepts) by values of the following indices: probability, separation, monoculture, margin-closed, frequency, stability estimate, CV, CFC, CU, predictability, similarity approach (Jaccard and SMC, aa), robustness with α = 0.3. We have concepts with a singleton as scope or intention for margin-closed and probability. The most interesting groups of indices (concepts) are listed with their frequencies. Frequency = 0.4: Extent, 2EstOIE, δ-TCFIs: for closed, non-applicable, non-applicable.

sections.heading: 4 Quality of indices
sections.text: The application of indices in practice mainly aims to meet the following challenges: selecting the most interesting concepts and the most original concepts from a series of concepts calculated in a noisy context, and stopping the grid construction process to avoid the calculation of exaggerated concepts.

sections.heading: 4.1 Rank Correlation
sections.text: To determine how similar the indices are, we examined the similarity of the concept of ranking by index values. The pair similarity of the indices is measured by the Kendall-tau correlation coefficient [42], this coefficient takes into account not only an absolute rank, but also a relative position.We randomly generated 4 groups of formal concepts with the following densities (the rate of the "1" in context): 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.4. Each group consisted of 100 formal contexts with the number of attributes ranging from 10 to 50, and the number of objects varied from 40 to 80. Variance in stability within the group of paired correlation is quite small (no more than 0.05) and does not depend on context density (p-values of the Levene test are less than 0.05). Since the values investigated cannot be considered as normal (based on D'Agostino and Pearson test), the Wilcoxon test was used to compare the mean values of Kendall indices.

sections.heading: 4.2 Integral Stability Indices: Best Approximation of Stability
sections.text: The Integrated Stability Index as a stability component can be used to obtain stability estimates. In this context, we consider the problem of approximation of stability with respect to different levels of the Integrated Stability Index. Since the scope of concepts varies from 0 to | G |, for each concept we have taken the degree of stability as a function of the size of the set A, to be precise, the level is defined by formula [Rate к | A |], where 0 < rate < 1. To find the best rate, we used randomly generated formal contexts (described in the revision subsection) of different densities: 0.1, 0.2, 0.3 and used simple linear regression. The jten Integrated Stability Index was taken as a regressor and the stability index as a dependent variable. Scatter charts of the investigated indices are given in Figure 3, and as can be seen from the diagrams, the assumption that the first stability rate is not a small one = 0.1 for most of the estimates.

sections.heading: 4.3 Noise Filtering
sections.text: In practice, one is usually faced with noisy data. Even a small noise rate can lead to an exponential explosion in the number of formal concepts [29]. In this context, we are investigating the ability of indices to select original concepts from the set of concepts calculated in a noisy context. We took 5 formal concepts, the grids of the first four of them have a fairly simple structure (see Figure 4) and the last one is a fragment of mushroom data set 1 consisting of 500 objects and 14 attributes. 1https: / / archive.ics.ucis.edu / ml / datasets / mushroom dataset We inserted different amounts of noise into the contexts as follows: each input changes with a given probability (noise rate). For "noisy" grids, we identified original concepts and considered them as a binary classification problem. We calculated the AUC (Under the Area Receiver) from each operator curve.

sections.heading: 5 Generic approach to the assessment of closed itemsets
sections.text: In addition, some indices have been proposed to evaluate associative rules - a part of FCA. A list of formulas is given in Table 2 to make the paper self-contained. More detailed information about the listed indices can be found in [43, 44, 45]. Also, note that association rules indices can be easily adapted to concept evaluations by selecting other concepts and applying the index to pairs "a selected concept, an evaluated concept." In this case, we propose instructions on applying arbitrary indices to closed items, starting with the personal perspective on concept interest. We define the following: 1. Some "internal" / "external" properties of the concept itself. In this case, homogeneous elements are considered equivalent. 2. Effects of the element on element capture. Here, a metric is applied to a set and its elements: f (element).

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we consider various approaches to degrading interesting formal concepts (closed item sets and corresponding transactions), we examined existing indices for concept selection, and proposed a general scheme for adapting an arbitrary index to concept evaluation. The results of our experiments allow us to distinguish groups of correlated indices and identify those of them that can be used to analyze noise data. It has been shown that the noise that filters the quality of indices largely depends on the structure of the concept grid rather than on the noise rate. The strongest dependence of filter quality on noise rate corresponds to stability estimates. Even a small amount of noise added to the data can significantly alter the grid structure that results in distorted values values values values values values of neighboring indices. We also proposed a general method for selecting and designing interesting attributes max indices that fit index-based characteristics well (the use of this notebook-based index in a particular description).

6 Separation The index was introduced in [29] to estimate the specificity of the object-attribute relation of a concept with respect to the formal context.
7 Monocle The Monocle [31] is a method that defines concept weights based on a subset of concepts.
8 δ-Tolerance Closed Frequent Itemsets (δ-TCFIs) δ-TCFIs [32] uses a subset of children in a lattice to assess a concept.
Concept c = (A,B) is δ-TCFI iif it meets the following condition: ∀d = (C,D), such that |D| = |B|+ 1, supp(D) ≥ (1− δ) · supp(B), where δ ∈ [0, 1] is a tolerance factor.

CV deals with the probability of an extent given attributes from an intent, CFC takes into account the relation between all attributes from a context and an intent of a formal concept, and CU characterizes how much an attribute from an intent is specific for a given concept rather than for a formal context [39].

metadata.abstractText: Formal concepts and closed itemsets proved to be of big importance for knowledge discovery, both as a tool for concise representation of association rules and a tool for clustering and constructing domain taxonomies and ontologies. Exponential explosion makes it difficult to consider the whole concept lattice arising from data, one needs to select most useful and interesting concepts. In this paper interestingness measures of concepts are considered and compared with respect to various aspects, such as efficiency of computation and applicability to noisy data and performing ranking correlation.
